title: Transfer images beforehand
content:
Role Location
Suite administrator Bastion node

Before you deploy the suite, you need to download the suite images from Docker Hub or other registries and then upload the images to your registry.

If you have already uploaded images to your registry, skip this step. 

Generate the Image Set

Before downloading and uploading the images, you need to generate the image set for your installation. Use the steps below to generate a download bundle for helm based installations.

  1. Log on to the bastion or first control plane node, and then navigate to the $CDF_HOME/tools/generate-download directory.
  2. Run the generate_download_bundle.sh command together with the options required by your deployment. For the full list of command options, run the command with the -h option. 
    generate_download_bundle.sh -f <image_set_file> [ -d <output_directory>]

    Where:

    • <image_set_file>: The absolute path to the image set file. To locate this file, untar the esm-1.0.0+2x.x-xxx.tar  and check the scripts folder. 
    • <output_directory>: The directory where the script saves the offline-download.zip file. If you don't specify a value, the script saves the file to the default directory, which is the current working directory.

    Example command:

    • For commercial deployment 
      generate_download_bundle.sh -f  <ESM_Helm_Chart-2x.x.x>/scripts/image_sets/_image-set.json -d /tmp
    • For FedRamp deployment 
      generate_download_bundle.sh -f  <ESM_Helm_Chart-2x.x.x>/scripts/image_sets/_fedramp-image-set.json -d /tmp

    You will see a similar message indicating that you have successfully generated the offline-download.zip file:

    INFO offline-download.zip is generated under /tmp
INFO For more details, please refer: /home/centos/cdf/log/generate_download_bundle/generate_download_bundle.20240129084204.log
    The generated file contains the image download bundle. This bundle downloads the images required for installation.

Download the required installation images

  1. Log on to the bastion node. If the bastion node can't access Docker Hub, transfer the  offline-download.zip  file to a Linux server that can access Docker Hub.
  2. Extract the .zip package to a directory. If you can't access Docker Hub directly, set up the HTTP/HTTPS proxy. For example, run the following commands to set the HTTP/HTTPS proxy. Replace the placeholders with your actual server and port. 
    export http_proxy="<http://PROXY_SERVER:PORT>"
export https_proxy="<https://PROXY_SERVER:PORT>"
  3. Go to the directory you extracted the offline-download.zip package into.
  4. Run the following command: 
    ./downloadimages.sh [-u <username>]  [-d <image download directory>] [-c on|off] [-o <org name>]
    Where:
    • Replace <username> with the Docker Hub username.
    • If you don't specify the credentials here, you will be prompted to specify them when you run the command.
    • <image download directory>: The directory where the container images will be downloaded. The default value is /var/opt/cdf/offline.
    • The -c option is used to verify the digital signature of the images during the download. The default setting is off, which doesn't verify the signature.
    • <org name>: The organization in the image registry that contains the images for installation. By default, this is hpeswitom. This option is mandatory if you aren't using the default organization name.

    To see the full list of options for the downloadimages.sh command, run the following command:

    ./downloadimages.sh –h
    The command also has a -p option to provide your password. The -p  option doesn't support single quotes (that is, don't include single quotes in the password).

    By selecting the -p option, you are disabling or bypassing security features, thereby exposing the system to increased security risks. By using this option, you understand and agree to assume all associated risks and hold OpenText harmless for the same.

    OpenText encourages you to use some other password options, which aren't provided by OpenText. By implementing the -p option, you may expose the system to increased security risks. Upload the images

Follow these steps to upload the installation images to your external image registry:

  1. Log on to one of the bastion nodes. The node must be able to connect to the external registry.
  2. Run the following commands to retrieve the username and password of ECR.

    Make sure you have already installed AWS CLI version 2 when configuring bastion:

    ecrUserName=AWS
ecrUserPassword=$(aws ecr get-login-password)
ecrURL=<aws_account_id>.dkr.ecr.<region>.amazonaws.com

    Where: <region> is your AWS region. 

  3. Go to the directory you extracted the offline-download.zip package into.
  4. Run the following command to upload the suite images to the external registry: 
    ./uploadimages.sh -r $ecrURL -u $ecrUserName -p $ecrUserPassword -d <image download directory> -o <org name> --cleanup --aws-region <region>
    Where:
    • <image download directory>: The directory to which you downloaded the container images. The default value is /var/opt/cdf/offline. Specify the -d option if the images aren't in the /var/opt/cdf/offline/ directory. You can use the -d option multiple times when the images are in different directories. The images can be the images downloaded by downloadimages.sh. Make sure the image file type matches the file extension. 
    • <org name>: The organization in the image registry that contains the images for installation. By default, this is hpeswitom. This option is mandatory if you aren't using the default organization name.
    • --cleanup: Delete the image source folder to save disk space. It only works when all images are uploaded successfully.
    • <region>: is your AWS region (default: "us-east-1"). 

    To see the full list of options for the uploadimages.sh command, run the following command:

    ./uploadimages.sh -h 

  5. Wait until the images are successfully uploaded. Your terminal should resemble the following: 
    Upload-process successfully completed.
